summary: Donate to a good cause and receive an unopened Game of Thrones Tarot Deck (pictured below) in your mailbox! Also, check out this...
body:
Donate to a good cause and receive an unopened Game of Thrones Tarot Deck (pictured below) in your mailbox! Also, check out this fun competition to win other prizes.

(Sorry, Funko Pops not included!)

What you need to do:

  1. Message me either through DM or a comment in the notes of this post inquiring if this is still available, as I only have one and first come, first serve.
  2. Donate $35 to the charity drive, making sure to leave a comment with your Tumblr URL and “GoT Tarot Deck.”
  3. Let me know when it’s all done and I’ll get your prize to you ASAP.

If you can’t donate, please reblog to spread the word on this great charity.

blog.name: jackoshadows
blog.title: Jak O' the Shadows
blog.description: I’m not going to swear an oath I can’t uphold. Talk about my father if you want. Tell me that’s the attitude that got him killed. But when enough people make false promises, words stop meaning anything. Then there are no more answers - only better and better lies. And lies won’t help us in this fight - Jon Snow.

tags: They are partners where she is currently vying to be queen of the 7K and he is warden of the North
summary: How do you explain being a fan of Jon and also a fan of Jonerys given the Season 7 writing really made Jon subservient to Dany? ...
question: How do you explain being a fan of Jon and also a fan of Jonerys given the Season 7 writing really made Jon subservient to Dany?  As a Jon fan, I hate the pairing because it is queen-servant rather than an equal relationship.
answer:
For fuck’s sake! I have like 10 anon messages about how Jon is ‘subservient’ to Dany. I really hope that none of you have female bosses at work and that you don’t feel ‘subservient’ and like a servant because she’s a woman. You may the type to call her bitchy and bossy just because she gave you a job and she dared to be a woman.

I mean, Jon was under several leaders before - he was Jeor Mormont’s steward. Was Jon subservient to him? Was Jon subservient to Stannis? Was Ned subservient to Robert? Is Sansa subservient to Jon?

It’s like some people just cannot stand the fact that the most powerful character on the show is a woman.  Their heads are exploding, unable to process this information. That’s why Dany cannot just be a good, powerful ruler for them. That’s why they have to make her mad, evil, a tyrant - that’s the only way Dany works for them as a character. 

That’s why when she is proud, commanding, and assertive , people see her as arrogant and entitled. Every character in Westeros is allowed to fight wars for their birthright - Robb, Sansa, Jon, Balon, Joffrey, Stannis, Renly - except for Dany. She’s not allowed to - she’s just supposed to accept her family’s massacre, the loss of her home, the assassins send by Robert to murder her and silently go away.

That’s why the violence committed by the male characters is totally justified and ignored, but Dany’s violence is picked apart under a microscope, scrutinized and used to label her bad. That’s why every vile, cruel act is okay in Westeros because it’s a medieval place with medieval rules but Dany’s acts alone are analyzed through the lens of 21st century morals.

Because she is a female character with a story arc traditionally played by a man and their small minds are unable to accept this. OMG, how can Jon - a man!!!! - bend the knee to Dany!!!! None of this outrage when the series started with Ned and all the Starks bending the knee to Robert Baratheon of course. When Jon got the Umber and Karstark kids to bend the knee for him. When Jon bend the knee for Stannis.

It is a fact that Dany is the most powerful leader in Westeros currently. By allying himself with her, Jon is getting the best help he can for the North and his people. She’s awesome for going North to help while halting her own personal campaign. He’s awesome for recognizing that she’s great and allying with her instead of fighting against her. And that’s the story the show is telling us.

blog.name: chitowngirl-12
blog.title: Chicago Diva
blog.description: I'm a fan of Jon, the North, and the Starks.  Not a Jonsa, but an ally because they are nice, rational people unlike other parts of GOT fandom that will remain nameless.  (Apparently I'm also a sexist crazy person for having bad, ungood opinions about Daenerys Targaryen!  And I also set up alts and post anonymous comments and talk to myself on AO3...  Sarc off.  Yeah, fandom is pissing me off right now.)

tags: when in doubt accuse your opponents of sexism!
also attack people who disagree with you as being crazy
summary: Dany-stans cannot deal with other people’s opinions
title: Dany-stans cannot deal with other people’s opinions
body: Got blocked by another Daenerys-stan LOL.  This one pretends to be a Jon fan.  Also attacks antis as misogynists.  And me as having issues for disagreeing with him.  God talk about annoying.  It is really the personal attacks that get to me.

summary: Once again, wHY do people ship jon and daenerys?
body:
Once again, wHY do people ship jon and daenerys?

This actually frustrates me, i just finished rewatching GoT with my roomies yesterday and they all ship jon/dany?????? they are RElAteD?!? Feels like the majority of GoT fans have some kind of incest fetish as they all ship this aunt/nephew relationship……… I get that they’re both sooooo pretty and kind but god damn people??? I told one of my roommates that it would be like her dating her sisters child, and SHE DIDNT EVEN FLINCH???????? There’s got to be someone else out there who doesn’t support this PLZ!!!!!


(ref my other post about how jon snow is a useless jellybean, and see jorah is the right man for daenerys )

blog.name: jackoshadows
blog.title: Jak O' the Shadows
blog.description: I’m not going to swear an oath I can’t uphold. Talk about my father if you want. Tell me that’s the attitude that got him killed. But when enough people make false promises, words stop meaning anything. Then there are no more answers - only better and better lies. And lies won’t help us in this fight - Jon Snow.

tags: Always doing what he thinks is right
Northern independence is not what's important right now
The King who knelt saved countless lives by kneeling
Like Theon says Jon does the right thing no matter how hard or unpopular it is
summary: Regarding Northern independence... and the King who Knelt.
title: Regarding Northern independence... and the King who Knelt.
body:
It’s slightly hilarious how certain Stark fans are so obsessed with Northern independence, when an existential apocalyptic threat is literally moving towards the North – acting exactly as the Westerosi lords focused on their petty politics while ignoring the real issue.

But anyways let’s explore Northern independence. Assuming that the show is hitting the same important plot points that GRRM told David and Dan would be happening in the books, then let’s see how it will happen in the books.

If Jon does indeed become KITN in the books, then it happens via Robb’s will. As per Robb’s will, Jon is legitimized – pushing him to the head of the line as the eldest Stark son. If Jon becomes KITN in the books, he does so as both Lord of Winterfell and KITN. No one is elected to this position, lol! That was just the show’s way of getting Jon to the same place he does in the books without Robb’s will and despite Sansa being there. Lord/Lady of Winterfell and KITN/QITN cannot be split as Winterfell is basically the seat of the KITN and his children will inherit WF. The show ignored all this because Jon is not going to be KITN/Lord of WF/Warden of the North for long considering his parentage. 

There is also a chance that Rickon becomes KITN since he is backed by Manderly and Manderly is playing a big role in taking down the Boltons currently in the books.

Now, if Jon bends the knee to Dany on the show, then the KITN (whether it’s Jon, Rickon or Bran) in the books will also most probably do the same. And just like Torrhen Stark, the KITN would have the authority to make that decision. It could be that several Northerners disagree with this and split from Jon – as they did with Torrhen Stark. But it’s Jon’s decision as KITN and final.

Jon is used to making unpopular decisions that go against the grain. He got assassinated the last time he enforced a highly unpopular decision – to let the Wildlings past the wall. He was the only one who thought it was the right decision – even Edd disagreed! But he went ahead and did it anyway – and that’s Jon. He went south to meet Dany – against the advice of every single person in the North – even Lyanna Mormont. But he did it – because as Tyrion points out, getting weapons and men for the depleted North was worth the risk. He went on a dangerous wight hunt – again, against everyone’s advice because he needed to convince people of the real threat beyond the wall.

This is who Jon is as a character. Even in the books, Jon is highly authoritarian – he does what he thinks is right and if anyone disagrees with him – he stops asking them for advice. On the show, Sansa complains to LF about Jon never asking for her opinions and she is right. He never does. Every single thing she asks him to do, he refuses.

As for the people who disagree with his decision…it will be interesting to see that next season. I think Arya and Bran will support Jon. The rest of them? Maybe they will break away from Jon and try to deal with the WW by themselves – good luck to them!

The North benefits from being in an union than outside of it. Ned certainly thought so, considering he continued under Robert’s rule despite hiding baby Jon from Robert’s wrath.

I think for the most part, the North will be okay with the Targaryen who has come to help. In the books, the North seceded because of the Lannisters and not the Targs. As the GreatJon says when he names Robb KITN:

MY LORDS! Here is what I say to these two kings! Renly Baratheon is nothing to me, nor Stannis neither. Why should they rule over me and mine, from some flowery seat in Highgarden or Dorne? What do they know of the Wall or the wolfswood or the barrows of the First Men? Even their gods are wrong. The Others take the Lannisters too, I’ve had a bellyful of them. Why shouldn’t we rule ourselves again? It was the dragons we married, and the dragons are all dead! There sits the only king I mean to bow my knee to, m'lords. The King in the North!

And as Manderly points out in his North remembers speech:

You saw them, the arrogant Ser Jared and his nephew Rhaegar, that smirking worm who wears a dragon’s name

That’s right. Manderly thinks that Rhaegar Frey is not worthy of the name. As we saw in the fire and blood excerpt, the Manderlys have ties to the Targs through the many alliances Alysanne made.

So if the KITN in the books – whether it be Jon, Rickon or Bran – decides to bend the knee to Queen Daenerys Targaryen, I don’t see the book Northerners having much of an issue with it. Of course the Northerners in the books are a bunch of hardy, loyal bad-asses and not the treacherous, whiny weather vanes they are on the show. So let’s see what they do next season. I am sure Jon will continue to do what he thinks is best – no matter their response.

And once they see Dany helping them fight the WW, I think they will accept her as Queen. In fact I could see them pushing for a Jon Snow/Dany marriage to make the Stark-Targ alliance even stronger.

reblog.comment:
It’s slightly hilarious how certain Stark fans are so obsessed with Northern independence, when an existential apocalyptic threat is literally moving towards the North – acting exactly as the Westerosi lords focused on their petty politics while ignoring the real issue.

But anyways let’s explore Northern independence. Assuming that the show is hitting the same important plot points that GRRM told David and Dan would be happening in the books, then let’s see how it will happen in the books.

If Jon does indeed become KITN in the books, then it happens via Robb’s will. As per Robb’s will, Jon is legitimized – pushing him to the head of the line as the eldest Stark son. If Jon becomes KITN in the books, he does so as both Lord of Winterfell and KITN. No one is elected to this position, lol! That was just the show’s way of getting Jon to the same place he does in the books without Robb’s will and despite Sansa being there. Lord/Lady of Winterfell and KITN/QITN cannot be split as Winterfell is basically the seat of the KITN and his children will inherit WF. The show ignored all this because Jon is not going to be KITN/Lord of WF/Warden of the North for long considering his parentage. 

There is also a chance that Rickon becomes KITN since he is backed by Manderly and Manderly is playing a big role in taking down the Boltons currently in the books.

Now, if Jon bends the knee to Dany on the show, then the KITN (whether it’s Jon, Rickon or Bran) in the books will also most probably do the same. And just like Torrhen Stark, the KITN would have the authority to make that decision. It could be that several Northerners disagree with this and split from Jon – as they did with Torrhen Stark. But it’s Jon’s decision as KITN and final.

Jon is used to making unpopular decisions that go against the grain. He got assassinated the last time he enforced a highly unpopular decision – to let the Wildlings past the wall. He was the only one who thought it was the right decision – even Edd disagreed! But he went ahead and did it anyway – and that’s Jon. He went south to meet Dany – against the advice of every single person in the North – even Lyanna Mormont. But he did it – because as Tyrion points out, getting weapons and men for the depleted North was worth the risk. He went on a dangerous wight hunt – again, against everyone’s advice because he needed to convince people of the real threat beyond the wall.

This is who Jon is as a character. Even in the books, Jon is highly authoritarian – he does what he thinks is right and if anyone disagrees with him – he stops asking them for advice. On the show, Sansa complains to LF about Jon never asking for her opinions and she is right. He never does. Every single thing she asks him to do, he refuses.

As for the people who disagree with his decision…it will be interesting to see that next season. I think Arya and Bran will support Jon. The rest of them? Maybe they will break away from Jon and try to deal with the WW by themselves – good luck to them!

The North benefits from being in an union than outside of it. Ned certainly thought so, considering he continued under Robert’s rule despite hiding baby Jon from Robert’s wrath.

I think for the most part, the North will be okay with the Targaryen who has come to help. In the books, the North seceded because of the Lannisters and not the Targs. As the GreatJon says when he names Robb KITN:

MY LORDS! Here is what I say to these two kings! Renly Baratheon is nothing to me, nor Stannis neither. Why should they rule over me and mine, from some flowery seat in Highgarden or Dorne? What do they know of the Wall or the wolfswood or the barrows of the First Men? Even their gods are wrong. The Others take the Lannisters too, I’ve had a bellyful of them. Why shouldn’t we rule ourselves again? It was the dragons we married, and the dragons are all dead! There sits the only king I mean to bow my knee to, m'lords. The King in the North!

And as Manderly points out in his North remembers speech:

You saw them, the arrogant Ser Jared and his nephew Rhaegar, that smirking worm who wears a dragon’s name

That’s right. Manderly thinks that Rhaegar Frey is not worthy of the name. As we saw in the fire and blood excerpt, the Manderlys have ties to the Targs through the many alliances Alysanne made.

So if the KITN in the books – whether it be Jon, Rickon or Bran – decides to bend the knee to Queen Daenerys Targaryen, I don’t see the book Northerners having much of an issue with it. Of course the Northerners in the books are a bunch of hardy, loyal bad-asses and not the treacherous, whiny weather vanes they are on the show. So let’s see what they do next season. I am sure Jon will continue to do what he thinks is best – no matter their response.

And once they see Dany helping them fight the WW, I think they will accept her as Queen. In fact I could see them pushing for a Jon Snow/Dany marriage to make the Stark-Targ alliance even stronger.

blog.name: jackoshadows
blog.title: Jak O' the Shadows
blog.description: I’m not going to swear an oath I can’t uphold. Talk about my father if you want. Tell me that’s the attitude that got him killed. But when enough people make false promises, words stop meaning anything. Then there are no more answers - only better and better lies. And lies won’t help us in this fight - Jon Snow.

tags: Jon Snow does not permission from Sansa to bend the knee
He did what he thinks is right
And it is the right decision
The North is made up of a bunch of whiny assholes on the show anyways
summary: Once again - for the people in the back (i.e) Jonsa shippers - Explaining Jon Snow, Part II
title: Once again - for the people in the back (i.e) Jonsa shippers - Explaining Jon Snow, Part II
body:
@thelawyerthatwaspromised

I don’t want to clog up another person’s post with our discussion, but your entire post was pretty terrible. You said:

“The whole shitty political!Jon theory came about to explain why Jon Snow would bend the knee completely unnecessarily without consulting anyone when he supposedly had no pressure to do so from Daenerys.”

The show very clearly outlined why Jon bend the knee. Just because you guys willfully ignore it because – OMG, how dare he not get permission from Queen Sansa – does not mean it did not happen. If you want it to be spelled out for you, here is what happens:

1.  Jon goes to Dragonstone for help.

2.  Dany apologizes to Jon for her father’s actions and Jon notices that she has not attacked KL with her dragons and Dothraki – Dany is not like Cersei.

3.  Dany wants Jon to bend the knee in return for her help. Jon refuses because he does not know her and does not acknowledge her right to the throne. They decide to continue the discussion on another date.

4.  Jon is a rebel KITN – considering this, Dany was far nicer to him than anyone else who has refused to bend the knee to their sovereign or leige lord. People who refuse to bend the knee are executed as traitors all the time in Westeros – as Jon points out to Sansa with respect to the Umbers and Karstarks. In fact Sansa was so incensed about the Karstarks and Umbers not choosing the Starks instead of the Boltons, that she even wanted their children punished and thrown out of their homes

5.  Jon spend his time on Dragonstone mining the very vital dragonglass – for which Dany provided her men to help him – and getting to know Dany from the people who followed her. As we saw on the show, they praise Dany as the queen they choose to follow, who is good of heart and wants what is the best for the people. Jon is impressed. As is Davos.

6.  When Dany returns from the field of fire 2.0 they have a very frank discussion on war and strength. As Dany rightfully points out to Jon, thousands of men died in very brutal ways in the BOTB, because the Starks wanted Winterfell back from the Boltons. Sometimes strength is terrible – but to be a leader in Westeros, it’s necessary. As GRRM himself has pointed out, it’s not just enough to be a good person to be ruler on the Iron Throne – one needs the strength to get it and hold onto it.

7.  Against advice, Dany risks her dragons to rescue Jon, Jorah and the others and then promises Jon – without him giving her anything in return – that she would help him and the North fight the WW. This finally makes it clear to Jon, that Dany is a good and righteous queen - a ruler who can put aside her life’s mission to defend the realm from an existential threat. As GRRM points out with Stannis:

“And it is important that the individual books refer to the civil wars, but the series title reminds us constantly that the real issue lies in the North beyond the Wall. Stannis becomes one of the few characters fully to understand that, which is why in spite of everything he is a righteous man, and not just a version of Henry VII, Tiberius or Louis XI.”

That Dany immediately does this, as soon as she sees the threat with her own eyes, puts her on par with Jon as a leader who understands what the real issue is.

8.  Jon recognizes this in Dany and bends the knee. That’s it. He thinks that Dany would  be a good Queen of the 7K. He is not obsessed about Northern independence (I will discuss this in another post) unlike some rabid Stark fans. He wants only what’s best for the North – and in his opinion  Dany being a good queen would be good for the North. And it would only be fair that after all the help that Dany is providing the North – without asking for anything in return – that Jon and the North in turn help her fight Cersei Lannister. Cersei is not going to leave the Starks and the North alone. Why not join with Dany to defeat Cersei? Rather than fight against Dany?

9.  Jon’s decision to bend the knee makes sense in every way possible – except for the folks obsessed with Northern independence. Like why? The North did just fine under the Targaryens for 300 years. They did fine under Robert Baratheon for 15 years. Ned enforced Robert’s rule over the 7k by helping him crush rebellions and taking child hostages. Robb wanted independence because of what the Lannisters did to his family.

10.  It’s clear that this obsession with Northern independence is only from a certain section of fans that want their fave to become Queen in the North. Sorry guys, that’s not happening.

So there it is. Jon thinks Dany is a good queen who is giving her all to protect the North and he thinks it’s better to fight with her than against her and therefore he bends the knee. The end.

Sometimes strength is terrible – but to be a leader in Westeros, it’s necessary. As GRRM himself has pointed out, it’s not just enough to be a good person to be ruler on the Iron Throne – one needs the strength to get it and hold onto it.

7.  Against advice, Dany risks her dragons to rescue Jon, Jorah and the others and then promises Jon – without him giving her anything in return – that she would help him and the North fight the WW. This finally makes it clear to Jon, that Dany is a good and righteous queen - a ruler who can put aside her life’s mission to defend the realm from an existential threat. As GRRM points out with Stannis:

“And it is important that the individual books refer to the civil wars, but the series title reminds us constantly that the real issue lies in the North beyond the Wall. Stannis becomes one of the few characters fully to understand that, which is why in spite of everything he is a righteous man, and not just a version of Henry VII, Tiberius or Louis XI.”

That Dany immediately does this, as soon as she sees the threat with her own eyes, puts her on par with Jon as a leader who understands what the real issue is.

8.  Jon recognizes this in Dany and bends the knee. That’s it. He thinks that Dany would  be a good Queen of the 7K. He is not obsessed about Northern independence (I will discuss this in another post) unlike some rabid Stark fans. He wants only what’s best for the North – and in his opinion  Dany being a good queen would be good for the North. And it would only be fair that after all the help that Dany is providing the North – without asking for anything in return – that Jon and the North in turn help her fight Cersei Lannister. Cersei is not going to leave the Starks and the North alone. Why not join with Dany to defeat Cersei? Rather than fight against Dany?

9.  Jon’s decision to bend the knee makes sense in every way possible – except for the folks obsessed with Northern independence. Like why? The North did just fine under the Targaryens for 300 years. They did fine under Robert Baratheon for 15 years. Ned enforced Robert’s rule over the 7k by helping him crush rebellions and taking child hostages. Robb wanted independence because of what the Lannisters did to his family.

10.  It’s clear that this obsession with Northern independence is only from a certain section of fans that want their fave to become Queen in the North. Sorry guys, that’s not happening.

So there it is. Jon thinks Dany is a good queen who is giving her all to protect the North and he thinks it’s better to fight with her than against her and therefore he bends the knee. The end.
